description.text:
edit2 7/2/15 I created a new version that is easier to print and assemble, no supports required. See it here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:937556 My wife has been working on a book based on the Vestal Virgins in Ancient Rome. (http://teralynpilgrim.blogspot.com/p/my-query-letter.html (link to her Query letter).
For her birthday this year I modeled up the temple using her research and other historical information. I then printed it out in a few pieces, painted, and glued them altogether. Modeled in solidworks. edit uploaded a set of .stl files that don't have the small pieces that force extra support to be built. these .stl files are found in the temple of vesta.zip file.

I printed this out in multiple pieces partially due to reducing support and partially due to stepping through the prints and finding tweaks necessary to the model. My original plan was to knock it all out in 2 pieces
Printed one of each on a replicator 2, PLA 2 shells, .2mm layer thickness and 10% infill. scaled all parts down by 35%. Painted, sanded mating surfaces and glued together
Also I was having issues with peeling, so I wound up tweaking the model to force my rep to build each large section on top of a portion of support material. The support acted as "shocks" which allowed the raft to peel but ensured that the actual bottoms of the pieces are perfectly flat. If anyone wants the .stl files without the small pieces that force the parts to print a layer of support I can upload those.
Parts are oriented incorrectly as well, make sure to rotate them to lie flat on the build plate.

description.text:
Walabot sponsored a Hackster.io meeting and provided a free Creator/Maker edition of their hardware. It did not have a case. I was able to get the board CAD and made this case.

It's designed so the board will slide-n-snap in. There is a thick mid section with a 30 degree "shoe" on the bottom. This will allow users to make their own mounting adapters for tripods, Go-Pro, etc. I've only made a "blank shoe" so far. Start with a 20x20x3 block and chamfer the edges 60 degrees.

The case was designed with details to hold the lid. I quickly made a lid but, as of this post, have not had a chance to print / prove the fit.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Resolution:

.3 worked fine, less for cleaner "snaps"

Notes:

The "shoe" section will likely need supports. I had trouble with auto-generated supports so I made a "shoe supports" file that you can add in if you desire (to slice both objects as 1). This shoe support STL should be centered under the board and worked great for me.

Material - Not ABS. I had good luck with PETG (3dxtech) & nGen (colorFabb)
There are a few 'nibs' on the side wall to hold the Walabot board in place if your print comes out on the large side. You can trim them if the fit is too tight.

Got CAD!

Somebody, via Hackster / Walabot, got me the CAD for the board! I designed from there. If you see a dimension that needs to be tweaked, I'm open to adjustments.

https://www.hackster.io/walabot/discussion

https://walabot.com/community

description.text:
Storage box filament gland with two holes. I spaced them to roughly match the spacing of the extruders on my i3 MK2-MMU. As long as you don't change the base size, you should only have to print one jig, which is just the plate piece with holes. The large holes are 10mm and the smaller corner holes are 5.2mm. I used a 3/8" twist drill bit for the larger holes, and 13/64" twist drill bit for the smaller holes, and then dremeled the large ones out a bit to make the fit easier.

Hardware Used:

  • M5-0.8 heat-set inserts (8x per pair) https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0754MY5H8/
  • M5-4 push-in fittings (4x per pair) https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00RN3KKWA/
  • M5-0.8 screws of sufficient length (4x per pair, I used M5x10mm)

print_settings.Printer:: BIBO2 Touch Dual Extruder X Laser

description.text: I needed some M3 screws, but of course, what I wanted wasn't available in a single kit. I had to purchase a kit with many lengths, but it didn't have any nuts or washers (third picture, left box). Then, I had to purchase another kit just to get nuts and washers. That made it cumbersome because I would have to look in two boxes to get what I needed. So, the obvious solution was to create a custom box to hold all the screws, nuts and washers.

Printer:

BIBO2 Touch Dual Extruder X Laser

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

100 um

Infill:

100%

Notes:

All three parts need a brim (or raft) to keep them flat. The bottom part of the box needs support to hold the tang.

All three parts need to be printed with a brim so there is no warpage. In addition, the bottom also needs supports that show up under the locking tang. Once printed, it's very difficult to clean out the support material, so take a good look at the file to see what that tang should look like. There are a couple chamfers that are needed to allow the latch to hold, yet allow it to open when pulled. If you know a better way to print this with the tang hanging out at 90 degrees, do so -- and let me know how you did it.

All the pins for the hinges and latch are filament with the ends melted to create a head (see last picture).

I included TEMPLATE.XLS which is the label used to identify the parts. Print it on plain paper and cut it just outside the black lines. Use a small piece of double stick tape (or a dab of glue stick) to hold in place.

I did my best to copy the old box, but make it larger, and position the dividers where I wanted them. The hard part was making the latch. There is a very small edge on the inside of the opening. It's only .020" high, but this is required to grab the tang on the bottom part of the box. Luckily, this part needed no modification after it was printed because it would be tough to get in there.

description.text:
Many rear bike lights are held on by stretchy rubber straps - these are ideal to attach to the seatpost, but end up with the light pointing downwards where it is not so obvious to motorists.

This simple wedge is placed between the seatpost and light to angle it back up. A lip on the top stops it slipping out, as a wedge would tend to do.

The size is made for a standard 27.2mm dia tube, simply scale on the printer for other seatpost sizes.

I would like to thank everyone that helped me on the way and this is/was a project for a subject called Genius hour and I really don't know how to fill out the "THING INFORMATION". So yeah I give a big thanks to my teachers and to...everyone really.

description.text:
I saw a similar one of these on one of those "craft sites" for sale for some crazy silly amount, so I ended up just hiring someone to make me this file (yes I own full rights to the file) as I had planned to make 20-30 of them. Then I decided I would share the file with the world so anybody can print them and not have to pay that silly markup price.

You'll have to get the suction cups (can't print those, yet) but otherwise, feel free to edit, improve, remux, whatever: I'm putting this out in public domain for non-commercial use.

However, if you do happen to use / improve it, consider sharing it with the community or if you'd like, send me the updated files and I'll update the listing and give you credit.

Cheers!

This is a box I made for my youngest son, he really likes animals and especially lions

This is a pretty simple box with a lion head model attached to the lid.

There's a simple latch mechanism attached to the back of the lion head that let you lock the box.

I printed everything in PLA, 20% infill to give the lid some strength and supports everywhere (for holding the sides of the lid and the lion's teeth).

After printing you need to insert the lock part into the hole in the lid and glue it to the notch in the back of the lion head.

For the hinge I used a straitened paper clip, a piece of 1.75mm filament will also fit but will be tight.

Designed in Fusion 360 and printed on my Robo 3D R1+, if you print this model please upload a "make" with a photo I really enjoy seeing those.

description.text: Built this duct to replace the stock duct. Works great and looks better!

This is a remix of AlexCphoto's Octagon Candle Holder for 3D Printing. His version is for laser engraving. I have done some work on the model by trimming each intersection for better fitment and making a few new patterns for the sides. I have also went ahead and combined several pieces of the base into a single object as I saw no need to seperate. If anyone wants them separated, leave a message and I can upload.

If you chose to print this, you will need (4) Feet, (1) Base, (1) Top, and (8) Sides of your choice.

I needed a place to store my small drill bits and a box is just too boring, since I'm already known (among people who know me) as the one that builds robots I decided to design a drill bit holder robot.

I printed this in PLA, because the model has a lot of internal pockets that need support inside the model I used 20% infill.

The main body does not need supports, the arm does need supports.

The body-arm connection is intentionally loose to be forgiving for printer calibration issues, use glue to attach the parts.

The robot holds (all links to AliExpress):

  • 1/1.5/2/2.5/3mm drill bits, 10 each
  • 3.3mm drill bits, 10 pieces
  • Screw taps for M3 M4 M5 M6 M8
  • T-handle tap wrench

The robot also has holes in both legs to screw it into a base because I suspect it wouldn't be stable (there are hols for screws on the bottom and little slots on the back of the leg to insert nuts to hold the screws, in the end this is stabe and I didn't use them.

Designed in Fusion 360 and printed on my Robo 3D R1+, if you print this model please upload a "make" with a photo I really enjoy seeing those.

title: Connector for profile 5 20x40 90° with foot M6

description.text:
The connector ensures the connection between 2 profiles 5 20x40 with 90 ° corner.
The connector saves expensive automatic connectors and makes the construction very simpatic.
It is required per one connector:
4 x M5 countersunk screws 16 mm;
1 x threaded foot;
2 x M6 nuts.
I recommend to buy a foot with steel core, but a STL file is also available here.
This design allows very slight horizontal adjustments of the printer.
Profile 5 has 2 holes with Ø4.2mm, which allows to cut M5 threads in these 2 holes.
The foot has not been printed by me, but a similar part has already been successfully printed. This is a fairly small thread, so I would set the layer thickness to 0.1 mm and take the nozzle 0.2 mm. Although, in my opinion, a bought foot will fit much better.

title: Hex Driver Tool for Mini bed adjustment

description.text:
This project creates a hex screw driver using the Allen wrench that comes with the Monoprice Mini. It is used for leveling the printer bed. The L-shape Allen (or hex) is pretty awkward to use compared to this screwdriver design.

I designed this long thin tapered handle with a 15mm deep socket at the tip. The socket is slightly undersized for the 2mm hex so that it can be heated and shoved into the socket for a permanent connection.

Printer:

Monoprice Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed this object "Bed_Driver_Grip" standing on end. I used PLA at a temperature of 200C using slow/fine settings.

It printed great on the first try as shown. However, I think the the small diameter of the tip end combined with the hex hole pushed the printer's capabilities a bit.

This is the first tall object that I designed to be printed on end like this. I was happy to see it print so well.

The print bed used here is glass with hairspray.

Instructions:

1) Print this object.

2) Use the corner edge of a file to cut off the long end of the standard 2mm Allen wrench that is supplied with the Monoprice Mini.

3) Use pliers to hold the long Allen part while heating it with a lighter for about 5 to 10 seconds. Then push the Allen straight into the handle socket and hold it in place until cooled.

The hex handle design makes it easy to index degrees or number of turns and keeps the tool from rolling around. The tool is tall and slim to clear your fingers of the printer arm.

This is a light duty adjustment tool.

author: ichfred

description.text:
When I learned to make latkes with my grandmother, she always used a grater not a shredder for the potatoes and onion. I bought a Tefal Fresh Express machine to grate our potatoes, but the grater insert is far too fine. I decided to try making and printing one. It is not perfect, but it works OK.

I may try reworking it with slightly more aggressive teeth, but if I make them too aggressive, they would scratch the inside of the housing.

I made it in PLA as that was all I had, but I intend to get some polycarbonate from ProFab as it is tougher and can tolerate higher temperatures, so should be dishwasher safe.

I designed it in TinkerCad, which took a while, and I had a few attempts. I am happy to share the TinkerCad file so you can edit it yourself if you want.

I sliced it in Cura, set for the finest resolution so that the teeth were well made and sharp.

The Xiami MiBox is a really nice Android TV streamer, but it does have a really strange shape that makes it not fit any square bracket.

I wanted to hang mine on a wall and needed some way to hold it in place so I designed this bracket.

This bracket is designed to hold the MiBox with the cables connected from below, that way the weight of the cables helps keep it in place.

The bracket has a place for one countersunk 4mm (or smaller) screw to connect it to the wall, the screw head fits inside the base of the bracket so it doesn't touch the MiBox

I printed this in PLA, this model needs support everywhere and some infill (10%-ish should be enough), the support is a little hard to remove because it has slanted surfaces on both sides, just remove it slowly and carefully.

Note that the bracket covers the USB port, this is simply because I had to put the support somewhere and the streamer can't be used if I blocked the power or HDMI connectors.

In the end I didn't use this bracket because I needed to connect the cables from the side – so I designed a different bracket that I'll upload as soon as I take some photos of it – watch this thing or follow me if you are interested.

description.text:
As the Joel Bot rises it looks for new avenues to gain a foothold in our society. It has thus begun adopting likenesses of others to lull the communities into a false sense of security. Be vigilant and you can spot them. You an also hear it chant "All your subs are belong to us."

A mash-up of Daniel Noree's scan and Apyrodesign's Joel Bot inspired by Lady Muse. Please check out these awesome creators and enjoy.

Meshmixer import

I opened first the Daniel Noree scan and then appended the Joel Bot. With the 'Edit' tools I could scale, move, and plane-cut the scan to fit, roughly, the Joel Bot.

Sculpting

In the sculpting tab I used the 'Move' brush with adjusted size and lowered strength to get a better fit between the two models. For instance the ears and neck of the scan were pulled "into" the bot. This gave it more of the mask look I had been aiming for.

Combining and Finishing

Once satisfied with the models relative to each other I did a Boolean merge. This is different then a combine which only links the models and the extra polygons are still "inside" each other. The Boolean merge fuses the polygons and all extra geometry is lost, intentionally.

Using the sculpt tool 'smooth-shrink' I cleaned up some of the areas between the merge.

to get the chin and beard scan into a better printing state (not going for a "true" reproduction just printable likeness) I alternated between move and smooth-shrink tools so nothing would be printing in air. You can see the slice example of how all the layers build on top and there are no parts being generated in open space (these appear like a torus [donut] or dot with circles around indicating the "top" of a peak).

Cookie cutter from the logo of the band Everytime I Die.

So I redesigned the mount.
The distance to the motor has been increased by a few cm.

title: Variable holder for optical z-endstops for Prusas Mendel

description.text:
This optical endstop holder is used for a precise adjustment of the z-axis. The basic idea of the endstop fixture is from Prusa's Mendel project (endstop-holder.scad).
https://github.com/prusajr/PrusaMendel The basic idea of the vertical adjustment is similar to "Vertical Adjustable Opto Z Endstop Holder" from LittleDangerous
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23858

Adjust the size parameters in the scad file for your printer and print it.
Or you can just use those uploaded files for printing:
1 x VzE_wheelV2.stl, 1 x VzE_holderV2.stl, 1 x VzE_endstopV2.stl

1 x springs 5.4 mm x 17.5 mm
7 x M3 nuts
1 x 35 mm M3 HexBolt (total threaded)
1 x 40 mm M3 HexBolt (half threaded, half smooth)
1 x 20 mm M3 HexBolt
2 x 15 mm M3 HexBolts
5 x M3 washers

Take the 40 mm HexBolt and decapitate the bolt's head - not your finger!
There are several ways how to assemble it, but lets describe my way.
Drill the holes of the endstop-part for some time using a 3.0 mm driller. The bolt must slide very smooth through these holes. It will also work with a 3.2 mm hole, but then the holder will shake a little bit. Secure both bolts as shown with nuts on the holder part. You need the spring above the thumb wheel on the black bolt. Use grease on the other long silver guiding bolt. Put 2 washers above the thumb wheel. The thumb wheel's nut is pointing towards end of the bolt. Make sure both bolts are parallel and the spring is not interfering with the threaded bolt.
The last photo (V1.0) shows how to assemble it without cutting a bolt's head.

Version 2.1
  • redesign of the holder, enabling two side mounting
  • redesign of the wheel for more grip
  • added spring centering to avoid interference with the threaded part of the bolt.
  • changed dimensions for a smooth gliding of the decapitated hexagonal bolt.
  • added more clearance for better fitting of nuts
    • Version 1.0
  • use VzE_plate_old.stl if you want to print the old design
  • use VzE_v1_old.scad to adjust parameters, if you need to

History: The “Star of David” logo was on the first Dodge Brothers car built, in 1914, and was last used on the 1938 Dodge. In 1914, when the emblem was first used, interlocking triangles (the “Star of David”) were not even associated with Judaism, to most people. Club writers suggested:
1: A medieval symbol of mysticism and the joining of mind and body, or, in this case, the joining of two brothers.
2: An abstraction of the square and compass of the Freemasons.
3: A representation of the Dodge City lawman’s badge. Horace Dodge apparently enjoyed accompanying local police on their runs, and likely would have appreciated the Dodge City reference.

title: Low-Tech 3D Scanner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE
The original files had a feature missing which would make assembly difficult. Correct files have now been uploaded.

You will need a smart phone and relevant photogrammetry app to complete this as an actual scanner (SCANN3D, for example).
The idea was to make as simple a scanning device as possible for small objects. No lasers, lenses or mechanical parts, 'flat-packed' so that even people with poor quality print results can assemble it and get some use, while using a relatively small amount of filament to print off. A few drops of decent superglue are all that's required to assemble it.

The turntable plate is indexed with marks, these line up with one of the three corner posts on the triangular frame. Rotate the plate 1,2,4 or 6 marks at a time for each photo. The app will stitch them together when done to produce a 3D scan.

TIP It works best if printed all in one colour, ideally white. You can then surround the turntable with a white paper background 'wall' to achieve better results from your chosen photogrammetry app.

You will have to provide your own elastic band.

The Delta 5 Race Timer is an innovative, cost effective solution for keeping track of race laps when racing FPV (First Person View). The designer of the Delta 5 Race Timer is Scott Chin. The system is open source, and utilizes the video transmitter frequencies instead of traditional transponders. For more information about Delta 5 Race Timer, visit the following web site:
https://github.com/scottgchin/delta5_race_timer
The Delta 5 Race Timer system can also work with a native lap timing software:
https://www.livetimescoring.com/

Before you get started
It is a fantastic system and you can keep up to 8 racers with it, and you can build it for about €150,- euros. Especially the integration with livetime makes this timer a great DIY race timer project.

If you live in the Netherlands and need help with building the delta5 race timer or want to have this race timer case printed for your own build. Then you can also contact Dutch Drone Squad:
https://www.facebook.com/dutchdronesquad/ or [email protected]

They have experience in building and printing this delta5 race timer (case) and are happy to help you.

What to be aware of...
If you have never used a linux based / command line system before, you may have some challenges with the Raspberry Pi setup. Fortunately, the setup process for getting a raspberry pi up and running is pretty easy.
Basic soldering skills, and soldering equipment are going to be needed. I assume that you're probably already in the RC hobby if you're reading this, so this shouldn't be a problem for most people.

Hardware
First, decide how many nodes you want to set up. One node can monitor one video frequency (in the 5.8 ghz range). The hardware currently supports up to 8 nodes. Please note: the software currently doesn't allow switching, and only monitors one channel per node. This means that the hardware is a bit more costly, but the lap times are going to be very accurate with the highest resolution possible.
All hardware required is listed on the Github link above, but I'll summarize it here and also add a few additional parts that I used. I purchased almost all of mine from Banggood. Prices listed are from there as of the time of writing this.

Each node requires an Arduino Nano. At banggood (Geekcreit® ATmega328P Nano V3) they sell clone versions for €2,50 and they work fine.

Each node also requires an RX5808. This is the video receiver. €8,- each on Banggood.
A Raspberry Pi 3 Model B. €38,-

1K resistors: Quantity 3.
100K resistor: Quantity 1. This is per each node. (Total of 24 1K resistors, 8 100K resistors if building 8 nodes). I bought them from Conrad in sets of 100 for €3,- per set.

You will need one 5v 2.5A voltage regulator. This will be sufficient for powering all 8 nodes, which should draw around 2A of current (including the Rasp Pi). I recommend this one: https://www.pololu.com/product/2850 Cost: €12,-

You will need one 3.3v 2.5A voltage regulator. This will be sufficient for powering all 8 receivers, these also work at 5v but give less heat at 3.3v. I recommend this one: https://www.pololu.com/product/2849 Cost: €11,-

a set of 40pin female header connector sockets (40 pieces: € 4,20) and 40 pins male header strip (30 pieces: € 3,50). I used this so that I can switch both the arduinos and receivers if necessary.

Other stuff:
You will need an SD card for the Rasp Pi. I recommend minimal 8GB.
As power connector I used an xt60 plug so you can connect a lipo, but also have a DC jack plug to xt60 so that a regular transformer also fits. Pay attention when using a transformer that it gives enough output power, but also not too much! 12V - 1A works fine. You can also check if it is enough by connecting the PI to a screen and watching during startup if you do not see a yellow thunder symbol.

You will need to decide how you want to connect to it. Many people just use a really long ethernet cable (eg. 40-50m). Wifi is also an option, but not really recommended because of the latency in a wifi connection.

About the case
The case allows for up to 8 nodes. 4 are mounted on the bottom, and 4 on the top in slots.
The 30mm fan cut out allows for cooling.
It is designed so that all inputs of the pi are easily accessible and you can easily change a PCB if necessary.
It has 4 holes so you can fix the raspberry pi with screws.

Credits
On behalf of Dutch Drone Squad we thank Boudewijn for the intensive cooperation to design this race timer case, you did a great job! And finally, I would like to give a credit to Techy G, I have used his text as a basis and also recommend to take a look at his version of the delta5 race timer.

description.text:
Xwing fighter Symphonie No. 5 Bethoven
...in "progress"

A friend needed a motorized arm for his Bedroom TV because his room was too small and he wanted to be able to watch TV while on bed and on the Sofa.

The arm can slide left and right, flip out, extend, swing 180° and tilt 45° on one side (Sofa side, see pics), it can be modified to tilt on both sides, but it could be modified to tilt on both sides, my friend didn't need it, so I didn't decide it, because I wasn't sure if the arm would stay up right when the motors are off.

WARNING: This is not by any means a finished design, some modifications are required to become functional.

I will not be finishing this design because my friend changed his mind.

Some suggestions/instructions if you decide to use this design:
Use a current sense sensor on the TV power cable so that you can detect when TV is on and move it to the default viewing position (goo.gl/QTiDZy)
Use an IR sensor and some of the Unused buttons on your TV remote to change the viewing position (goo.gl/WKKUBT - goo.gl/sdGkum)
Extend the arm first before flipping it out, and flip it in before retracting it, so that you don't smash your TV to the wall. Also make sure that you don't smash your TV to a wall when swinging extending etc.
The brown "part" in the design is a a leather piece that "slides" with the rest of the assembly to hide the mechanism. Some other means of hiding the mechanism near the base of the rotating arm is required, I suggest using springs so it's stretched.

title: Customizable(in Onshape): Cork / Insulation Holder for Heated Bed V2

description.text:
This is the second version (V2) of my heated bed insulation holder you can see here:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2753110

There I used a rubber band to connect the pieces fo the support, and some of you may use the bed at extreme temperatures or you have an enclosure so the rubber band will wear out pretty quick. That is why I made this part to connect the parts with a zip-tie or any wire will do it. The part can be customized directly in Onshape and then Exported to STL.

Here is the link:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/a6e6200091bc6d2379031f92/w/9fbd5d840a8adebd76acd0fd/e/b3d82b96b896c96e86859ab0

Customization - default value (min-max)

Bed PCB width - 215 mm (100-400)
Insulation width - 180 mm (80-380)
Insulation height - 5 mm (1.5-25)
Edge to hole - 3 mm (2-5)
Hole diameter - 3 mm (2-5)
Spring diameter - 7.2 mm (4.2-10.2)
Zip tie length (closed perimeter) - 230 mm (70-450)
Zip tie width 2.7 mm - (1.5-5)

The zip tie can be replaced with anything you want: wire, thread…

IMPORTANT
The height for the insulation support is 1 mm smaller than the insulation to press the insulation tighter to the bottom of the PCB bed, it is not a design flaw, that is how it is supposed to be (Image 5)

If you don’t have Onshape or you don’t get along with the customization, write a comment or a message and tell me the values you want to customise and I send the STL to you.

Step 0: Customize the thing for your desired dimensions: the zip-tie length is when closed/fastened. I recommend for zip-tie width to add +0.2 mm tolerance. e.g. if you have a 2.5mm zip tie then 2.7mm.

Step 1: Print 4x.

Step 2: Put the zip-tie through the 4 notches as seen in the Image

Step 3: Put the 4 pieces in the corners of the insulation pad and fasten the zip-tie to the desired diameter, but not too tight.

Step 4: Mount the Insulation(cork, cardboard,) plate under the bed with the washers/springs you already have. Fasten the zip-tie to its final tightness.

Step 5: Enjoy a warmer/quicker warming bed.

title: JGAURORA A5 Remixed Camera Mount for Bed!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
So I tried the original however two issues arose, the first is it set so far forward and the camera hit the gantry and second since the mount was centered, and the lens off center of the camera I could not get a complete view of the bed. So I remixed it into several configurations. Including the following:

Arm_Long_v1.STL: is a version where we lengthened the arms so it sits back further from the bed and gantery. It also has three (3) 1/4 inch holes to mount a camera or camera bracket to as one is centered and two are offset (for a camera with a center offset lens.

Arm_Long_v2.STL: is a version where we lengthened the arms so it sits back further from the bed and gantery. However has four M3 holes with openings for M3 nuts (either 10 or 12mm M3's will work see: http://amzn.to/2FsQj75 ). As this version uses the Camera Base_v.STL and it can sit either in the center or offset left or right.

Arm_Short_v2.STL: is a version with standard length arms and has four M3 holes with openings for M3 nuts (either 10 or 12mm M3's will work see: http://amzn.to/2FsQj75 ). As this version uses the Camera Base_v.STL and it can sit either in the center or offset left or right.

Camera Base_v1.STL: is the base for v2 Arms and has a 1/4 inch opening for a standard tripod bolt to pass though and mount a camera. You can also use a ball head like this http://amzn.to/2DkrDNv as well as a you can use a cell phone mount such as this http://amzn.to/2DnwL3E or even this http://amzn.to/2CT6uZX to hold your phone.

I would also recommend the ThiEYE 4k action camera http://amzn.to/2FtWxUc as it is a very lightweight 4k camera with great timelapse features!

Also if Interested in getting your own JGAURORA A5 check out the deals on Gearbest for them here https://goo.gl/efnSH4 as these folks have been great to work with and are huge supporters of the 3D Printing community!

To mount you will need to remove the two front bed leveling (tramming) nuts and lift up ad slide the arms into the bed rails. This will be somewhat tight to hold the arms tights and force (gently) the bed bolts back through the openings and return the nuts. Also watch the heated bed connector as it likes to pop off so you will need to pop it back on.

title: Flying Wing magnetic RX / FPV antenna mount and more
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my modular Flying /Fixed Wing antenna holder that i initially designed for my Sweepwings Flinch but it will works for all kind of wings. I was scratching my head all the time to find the best solution for mounting of both the RX and the VTX antenna. I came up with this simple mount that allows you to make 2 Pockets coming from your battery bay into the wing and frome there to the top of the wing. It utilises Neodymium Magnets (http://bit.ly/2DyNDnO) to connect the lid and the bottom part.

You simply draw the outline and inline of the bottom piece which is 20x20mm at the spot where you want your'e antenna to come out of the wing. Afterwards cut out the inner part and trim it back so can get both pieces togheter in. Glue the bottom part in and you're done.

Allways print the all the pieces in "Hard" materials like PLA the magnets should be pressfit but can also be glued in.

Except the mount for the horizontal antenna thats best printed in tpu and the magnets glued in place with CA glue

I came up with a few different lid's.

1: Unify pigtail mount

2: RX antenna mount vertical
(heatshrink your antenna to a ziptie and use two small zipties to secure it to the mount, punch a small hole in the wing to get the antenna through.

3: RX antenna mount horizontal
(you need additional rc antenna tubes Ø3mm like this one http://bit.ly/2EJA18M )

4: Normal vtx pigtail mount

5: two lids that allow you to route some cables through them

title: Shade for multi-head torchiere floor lamp

description.text:
This is a replacement shade for my multi-head torchiere floor lamp. The original shades were made of ABS or some other translucent white plastic that had gotten brittle and yellowed over the years. 1 had completely disintegrated, and the other 4 would crumble with the slightest pressure.
So, I decided to put my new 3D printer to good use an make new ones! I modeled a form that I find more pleasing than the original boring "cup" shape, and printed 5 of them in white PLA. I'm using BAMTack! PLA, but of course you can use any filament you like.

One important note: If you print these shades, you MUST use either low wattage CFL bulbs or, better yet, LEDs. Otherwise, the head generated by standard incandescent bulbs will likely soften the PLA and cause the shades to sag at best, and melt at worst. If you burn down your house, it's your fault. You have been warned.

Printer:

Creality CR-10S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20-30%

Notes:

The base diameter of the shade is 2.5" OD, and the inner cutout circle is 1.5" diameter. If that's different that what your particular lamp needs, then of course this shade will not work for you without modification.

My original shades had ventilation holes in the base. I eliminated these for 2 reasons:
1) Since I'm using LEDs, heat isn't an issue and it prints faster without them.
2) The ring that locks the shade in place was completely blocking the holes anyway. Great design. :)

In the photo of the shades installed, the color difference is because 3 of the bulbs are CFL and 2 are LED. I'm replacing the rest with LED tomorrow.

The 3 shades on the right are the new ones. The 2 on the left are the original shades, for size and shape comparison.

Should be no post-processing required, unless you elect to use a skirt or brim, in which case of course you'll have to clean those up.

The main shell prints in 2 passes, so you likely will have a seam running down one side. When installing, orient the shade so this seam faces away from the viewer for best aesthetics.

The inner diameter of the shade is a bit smaller than the original shades, so you might want to get someone with smaller hands to help with the install if you are a guy with big hands.

title: Kiss 24a esc guard (3 designs)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Kiss 24 amp ESC guards.

These fit my 24a Kiss ESC's after the ESC has had heat-shrink applied. I was using another version found here on Thingiverse but I had to slightly resize them to fit with the heat-shrink. That alone was no biggie but they were also kinda bulky.

I designed these a little lighter then some others found here on Thingiverse and I also only added one channel for the wire tie to save weight. V1 weighs in at 1.95g vs 3.7g for the ones I was previously using. I managed to save a total of 14.2g when including the wire ties.

I made three different designs identified by a version number. The photos include the version numbers to make it slightly easier to decide on what file to use and what one you like best.

Used on my Martian II frame.

May fit other ESC brands.

Enjoy, and may all your flights be smooth as silk.

description.text:
A hexagonal dice box, with 7 internal dice pockets to hold one each of the 7 standard polyhedral dice, with magnets to hold it closed. The top half comes in two flavors:

  • Blank
  • 5th Edition D&D Logo

It could be modified to show whatever logo you prefer! Other logos I know about:

  • D20 logo by Hoffa

For best results, print with wood filament. After the print, sand and apply your favorite wood treatment.

Also included is a middle piece, for creating dice box towers!

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I used a high infill only to give the final piece some more weight, as wood filament tends to be very light.

The middle piece needs a tiny bit of removable support for the lip. The rest can usually be accomplished just fine with bridges.

Magnetic Clasp

This dice box comes with pockets to fit 5mm diameter, 1mm thick magnets, which give the box a satisfying open and close action. I used these, but others will work fine.

Use some sandpaper to rough up one side of each magnet, then glue it into the pockets with superglue. If you don't roughen the surface, the magnets will be prone to popping out.

Be sure the correct side faces out! If you glue your magnets in wrong, the two halves of the box will repel rather than click together.

Modifying the Box

This box was made in Onshape, and can be viewed and forked here. In particular, the Logo sketch can be modified to put a different logo on the top of the box, or to remove it entirely.

If you create a new top with a new logo, feel free to remix this thing or let me know and I can post it here!

author: compudude1991

print_settings.Notes:: Print upside down with supports.

description.text:
Long story short, this is a mount that sits on the X-carriage to allow you to mount a laser for engraving.
The laser used was 500mw from a Neje unit, set at 100mm focal distance. In use I raise the z height by 60mm, plus the thickness of the item being burned into.
The laser goes to the laser/fan slot on the board.

I used inkscape with the J-Tech extension to generate the code, adding in a home command, the raise command an a pause prior to actual printing for final moving of the target object. I recommend watching some You-Tube videos on using Inkscape for using the plug-in if you haven't tried it before.

Disclaimer : I made this for my personal educational purposes - if you use it, it is at your own risk. Using lasers can be dangerous, make yourself aware of any safety precautions and follow them!.
VERY IMPORTANT NOTE When using the Laser output on the printer board, it appears to cause the laser to briefly light at full power on startup, when you change cards and when you start a print, maybe at other times too.
Wear your glasses at all times!!

title: DIY Spherical Rotating LED Kit POV Soldering Aid

description.text:
So when you build this thing it all goes according to plan until you get to this arc of LEDs, then the frustration sets in.

No problem just print this spacer, wrap a ruler with tape backwards (sticky out), stick it to the table, tape the spacer to the arc PCB, stick the LEDs to the sticky edge of the ruler, shove the arc up to the LED and tape down, you now have 2 hands to solder them on.

I had a problem with the pads on the board not being at the edge, if I would have thought about it at the time I would have ground the edge down till they were flush.

Happy making

title: CR-10, OEM Fan, Offset Nozzle, Strong Tabs

description.text:
Remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2562314

I printed the original design at 0.2mm layer and during install the mounting tabs cracked. After a few prints i liked the offset nozzle design to blow part cooling air right where it was needed as compared to a couple other popular designs. So in hopes of making it better: I reduced the hole diameter by 0.4mm on diameter ( its just snug on the threads now), I also added 0.5mm to each end of the mounting hole tabs and finally I stretched the small bevel over the whole width of the fan shroud so it was less likely to catch the print if it was going to lift.

No Raft required.
No Supports required.
Prints good at 0.2mm layers.

cr-10_oem_fan_nozzle_offset_stonger.stl is the original file. Use Version 2.

cr-10_oem_fan_nozzle_offset_stonger_v2.stl added 1-19-2018
Added a even more material around the mounting tabs.
Recontoured surfaces to removed weight and sharp edges.
Greatly reduced file size.
Added more Remix reference files to link parts together.

author: Ail

title: Closet Maid Close Mesh Wire Shelving Label Clip

description.text:
Closet Maid "Close Mesh" wire shelving is typically used in pantries and kitchen cabinets. This model creates a label holder that can be clipped directly onto the front of the shelving to help keep things organized. It is designed to accept a label generated on a Brother label maker using typical 12 mm wide tape.

The Customizer allows the user to modify the size of the clip and the height of the label tape, if desired. The clips that snap onto the shelf wires are set to be spaced out to the maximum allowable spacing that still ensures the entire clip is behind the label. The "Closet Mesh" wire spacing of 0.63"/16 mm is maintained automatically so the user can specify any label width. Note that too small of a label (i.e., one that isn't wide enough to span the full 16 mm wire spacing) will probably give some weird error and there is not protection built into the OpenSCAD file, so user beware.

Please let me know if you find an error or a way to break it. :-)

remixed_from.title: Tronxy p802m x axis belt tensioner

title: X Axis Tronxy p802ma Belt tensioner FOR TOOTHED BEARING - REMIX

description.text:
This is designed so that you can take a TOOTHED bearing and use that on your belt. It allows for a much straighter, better belt alignment, with higher accuracy on jerk movements. I used these bearings off amazon, but any 16 or 20 (20 is less accuracy) toothed bearing will work. Additionally, you will need 1x30mm M3 screw and 1-3 M3 nuts, depending on your preference. I used 3 nuts, one on the inside of both prongs, and 1 on the outside of the screw.

NOTE This is the same exact back piece as the original design.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01H3EY4X4/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

comments.text: Mechanically correct but could be made stronger (rounded edge, no nut hole)) see here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2594693 Use a M3 threaded rod fixed int the pulley bracket plus butterfly (or knob) nut. Note the thin arm allows auto-alignment of the pulley/belt, not mandatory though. And to adjust the belt tension: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2023765
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: I appreciate the thoughts. For the tronxy, this original is the only one I could find that worked. I'm not trying to reinvent the wheel, just remix his current design to fit my needs better, which was to have a toothed bearing in the tensioner. I'm aware there are better options, but those frankly don't serve a better purpose than this, for the amount of time I'd need to redesign this entire piece. The piece how it is works great for my needs, and it doesn't really need additional strength as you only want the belt so tight.

I printed four of these and taped them together so my daughter could make larger creations. I designed this so that if you place multiple copies next to each other, they will have perfect spacing for continuous designs.

I created this in ACAD 2018 using the STLOUT command. (Non-Binary)

description.text: I wanted clamping dogs that I could use with the stock Festool MFT fence and not use the miter gauge. This design fits with no slop in the MFT holes for precise alignment. In addition to the print for each clamp you need 2 M6x25mm hex bolts and nuts, you'll want a pair of these. One bolt goes down from the top into the nut in the lower knob. The head of the other bolt engages the track in the fence and the nut goes into the tightening arm in the back - if you screw the bolt in the right amount the level will lock and unlock the track with about a 90 degree turn. (2/25/2018) I've added an alternate bottom knob design which is bigger and easier to grab by hand. It can be used instead of the other bottom.

description.text:
This is a simple little thing that I whipped up in order to try and keep the element, dirt, mud, snow, rain, small ferocious animals, etc of of my stack. Conformal coating only protects you so much and I'm tired of loosing electronics to the winter spirits.

This thing is printed in TPU and is designed to slip over top of your stack. It stays in place by friction fitting over the standoffs.

This is not meant to be waterproof in any way shape of form, it's just a cover to try and keep the worst of the crap off your electronics.

There's 2 versions of this model, one with 16mm of internal clearance and one with 18mm. If there's any interest in this I can easily make versions to fit other stack configurations.

description.text:
This is a set of hangers and handles for the enclosure designed by Mike Kelly. It can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:681843 and
https://printedsolid.com/collections/enclosures/products/robo-3d-safety-enclosure-kit
Mike gets part of the profit from the printedsolid.com sales, so no worries there.

I have a few things on top of my rear enclosure (a fan, a filter, and a 3" tube going back into the enclosure) and this started to weigh down on the latches and make them slip. So I set up a more solid option that drilled through the cover AND added to the original option to make it more solid also. Take your pick.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Sand down the upper latch until it fits into the lower BEFORE mounting.

Insure Parts Fit Before Mounting

My parts were printed in ABS+ with my standard settings. The upper hanger would not fit into the lower, so I had to sand them down a touch, equally on both sides, until they fit. A snug fit is preferable and with the handles available, it's much easier to get off.

Build Instructions

Non-Drilling Option:
If you want to avoid drilling holes in the original Robo3d cover, use the Original Left and Right Hanger files. Thread and install 8 5mm M3 set screws (see link below) in the holes on each bottom hanger. Slide the hangers onto the case and tighten the set screws. It may help to put a small indention where the set screw would attach to keep the hanger from sliding. This can be done with a drill (yeah, I know this is supposed to be the non-drilling option) by barely tapping into the plastic where the set screw lines up.
The set screws are needed to avoid leaving the screw heads in the path of the extruder stepper motor when Z is around 60mm.

Drilling Option:
If the set screws do not hold, or if you want it to be very secure, drill two small 1/8" holes using the hangers as a marking guide. Secure the latches with the 8

The upper hanger attaches to the plexiglass and matches up with the 2 holes that are pre-drilled from printed solid. If you are laser cutting the acrylic yourself, you can either laser cut the holes or drill them using the hole drill jig provided (you only need one).

Hardware Needed:
Non-Drill Option:
8 - 5mm M3 0.5 Set Screws (https://www.amazon.com/Socket-Screws-Stainless-Wrench-Length/dp/B072XYL38Y)
8 - 15mm M3 0.5 Socket Head Screws
8 - M3 0.5 Nylon Insert Nuts

Drilling Option:
16 - 15mm M3 0.5 Socket Head Screws
16 - M3 0.5 Nylon Insert Nuts

description.text:
Rear antenna mount for the Zypher FPV Racing frame by Box'O'Props. You can purchase this frame here: http://boxoprops.com/zypher.html

This antenna mount will allow you to bend your antenna to the perfect angle and insure it will flex a good amount in the case of a crash, instead of ripping the SMA connector and antenna apart because it's firmly mounted to the 5mm carbon fiber.

The antenna base on this mount is designed for any number of antenna attachments. The standard SMA mount with a bolt on the opposite side, or the mount that comes with the TBS Unify. There are two ways to attach the Unify mount. Run the SMA connector through the mount from the board side and attach it with two 5 mm M3 screws into the mounting plate. The other is to detach the U.FL connector from the Unify board, run the cable through the mount from the back, then attach it from the board side with two 5mm M3 screws into the mounting plate.

The file is made for the original 25mm standoffs that come with the frame. If you've shortened the standoffs, I've included a step file that should allow you to modify it to your liking or you can just slice the bottom off with a really sharp x-acto blade.

comments.text:
Caution!
I am also a prosthetist and have been making prostheses for 30+ years. I love to 3D print items, just be careful of printing this for someone without taking the liability on yourself. I say that because the feet that are commercially printed are tested by the companies through at least 2 million cycles or steps to insure there is no failures of the feet. That may seem like a lot, but it is only about what a person walks in a year. Also the feet we buy from manufactures are rated for specific weight categories and their activities. So if you print this and give it to a person and in a month they fall when climbing steps and their hands are full or crossing a road and it snaps when they are in front of a car, this would be partially your responsibility. I have had components fail on my patients even with all of the testing done and it can be very devastating if they are doing an action that can cause problems if they fall and are not ready for it. The testing and the responsibility of making a foot is one of the reasons the foot itself can be expensive. There are over 200 types of feet now available for amputees in the USA. They range from firm feet to very flexible ones. Costs also range from $500 to over $100,000 for the foot alone depending on the foot. I know it seems like a lot, but think of now what goes into a prosthetic foot and what liabilities there are when you make one.
comments.author: JEFFROPP

comments.text: Sounds like you’re threatened that people can print this themselves without paying a ridiculous 100k fee. This is a middle finger to the medical profession who demanded compensation before health care is given. It’s a free open source alternative when y’all want to jack up the price when the materials you use cost $2000 max!
comments.author: JEFFROPP

comments.text: I'm not threatened at all, in fact I'd like to see this work. However there are three important parts of a prothesis. The first part is the components themselves, which is what this is. The second part is aligning the foot to the residual limb, if this isn't done properly a $100,000 is worthless because an amputee cannot walk with it, similar to a good and bad alignment on car tires. Third is the fit of the socket on the amputee's limb, again if this hurts, the prosthesis is useless because of the pain ensued from a poor fitting will render it unable to wear and possibly worse cause ulcerations on the amputee's limb. Now if all of these items are successful then the prosthesis should be wearable. If this could be done with these parts then that's great. If these parts fail though when someone is walking on it and you printed these for that person and they hurt themselves, then how much money do you have for a lawsuit. This isn't from me, but the lawyers in the US and if you are outside the US, then you are much luckier. I often give legs away when insurance can't pay so while money is important it isn't what drives me. I do use 3-D scanning, 3-D printing, laser cutting and engraving, specialized fitting systems, silicone, elastomeric gel, computerization in feet, knees, elbows and hands. We are up to date on making sure HIPPA guidelines are followed and that we are a certified prosthetic and orthotic facility. So good luck with printing this for all the amputees Runningfox!
comments.author: Runningfox

comments.text: I’ve already gone up against the ATF and congress and won when I helped cofound DEFDIST. I’ve sued Wells Fargo twice and won. Papa John’s, Home Depot, McDonald’s, AOL and won. I’ve helped introduce the world to 3D printing guns. I’ve already downloaded the foot. I cannot be sued due to the fact I’m giving the files away for free. With a link who developed it and produced it. In thus I cannot be sued by a cripple who printed it themselves. Just like people who print the guns I’ve uploaded to the internet in 2008 I cannot be sued by any weapons manufacturer.
comments.author: JEFFROPP

comments.text: Wow Runningfox, you seem like quite an insecure person who doesn't value anything but their own opinion. Look at all those "things" you've "accomplished" but don't pertain to what is actually being talked about. It s sad that you felt it's acceptable to use the term cripple... You demonstrate a lack of emotional intelligence.

comments.text: "Cripples" really Runningfox,,,,,

comments.author: JEFFROPP

comments.text: It depends on if you are molding the remaining foot or the residual limb (amputated limb). It is very hard to cast or scan either one and make a reverse duplicate of it. It is actually easy to scan the residual limb, but to make a socket that goes on the limb and is comfortable is very hard. There are soft spots on the limb and boney areas, and if the socket (what goes over the limb) is not proper it can cause ulcerations and infections that cause a lot of problems. If it is fitting well though, it can be something that allows them to walk without anyone knowing.
comments.author: Ultrachangon

comments.text: “Very hard to scan” B u l l s h I t ! A NextEngine 3D scanner or cheaper handheld variants can scan 1 million points per sq inch on a person and replicate a exact .stl file or a.obj file. You’re purposely giving misinformation

comments.text:
As you were interested, here's a couple of International standards which would help with validating the robustness of such a (commercial) device. If this is for home-made use, you bear the personal risk.
https://www.iso.org/standard/37546.html
https://www.iso.org/standard/70205.html
comments.author: r0ds

comments.text: I have seen the testing machines, but do not know how to make them. The idea would be to put the pylon "pipe" into a clamp and then have it push down on heel and forefoot forces, rolling from heel to toe, the repeat. These are very robust machines and what I've seen have been made by the companies that make the feet. I believe there is also an international standard that has to be met. Most foot manufacturers not only sell their feet here in the US, but also internationally, which have certain standards. I am familiar with the College Park foot, the Truestep. This was started by an inventor who saw the movie Terminator and decided to create a foot for people to use with that design. He had gone through many different designs, using stainless steel, composites and a large varied about of materials. Since 1986 they have been making feet for amputees.
comments.author: r0ds

comments.text: Another thing is that when a person walks, they put between 2-4 times their body weight in forces through their leg. So if it just is for a 100b person the prosthesis needs to be able to take 400 lbs of normal forces going through it, just to be safe.

title: Modular Tool Tray System for Creality CR-10 3D Printer

description.text:
Modular Tool Tray System for Creality CR-10 3D Printer

Simple but effective modular tool tray system for the popular Creality CR-10 3D printer.
No mountig material needed. Just latch the tool trays in the aluminium frame (inside or outside). The 45 degree angled mounting bracket guarantees a perfect fit and stability!

There are 4 versions of the tray:

  1. Tool tray (24 cm) with sideslots for allan wrenches and SD cards
  2. Tool tray (24 cm) without sideslots
  3. Tool tray (12 cm) without sideslots
  4. Tool tray (12 cm) with flip cover (do not mount inside or in front as the flip cover could interfere with the heatbed)

Can be mounted in the following locations on a CR-10:

  • 2 x 12 cm on the front (inside or outside)
  • 2 x 12 cm in the back (inside or outside)
  • 1 x 24 cm + 1 x 12 cm on the left side (inside or outside)
  • 1 x 24 cm + 1 x 12 cm on the right side (inside or outside)
  • 2 x 24 cm on top front and top back

Storage for:

  • Spatula
  • Tweezers
  • Sidecutter
  • Glue stick
  • Screwdriver
  • Allan wrenches
  • SD cards
  • etc.

Dimensions:

  • Width: 6 cm
  • Height: 1.5 cm

print_settings.Notes:: White PLA

description.text:
Tried out BlocksCAD when I saw the snowflake contest. After a few hours of messing about and trial and error I started to put together a customisable snowflake based on the real world snowflake principle of the fibonacci ratio.
I'm not a coder so it always takes me some time but the visual block method of BlocksCad enabled me to try different things out and go back and try again until things started to go the way I wanted them.
I often have to sit back and grab a pen and paper to try to work out the algorithms but, with a bit of research into the behaviour of real snowflakes, I managed to get something that looks pretty decent when printed out - I suppose it looks better printed because all the imperfections of my printer (a relatively new Anet A8) mimic the real imperfections of the natural world.

Play around with the variables to see what different shapes you can make: most are self explanatory apart from the 'branch_length" one which returns a longer length with a smaller number.
As I say, I'm not a coder so if anyone can point out some more elegant ways to do what I'm doing I am always impressed to learn.

description.text:
It's not great admittedly but it functions as a holder ok.
My first design so it's not gonna be a show stopper.
Well it's actually revison 3 as the first 2 didn't go well at all ;)

This is a latch to use on plastic binding tape - the sort you usually find on large boxes, and throw away. It consists of three parts and a handy tool to tighten it. I sliced on Cura and printed the base standing on it's smaller end. Printed in PLA at 1.2mm & 35% infill.

Next day: - I discovered that strap material is also available in a 13mm wide version, for this I made the parts 10% wider when I sliced them. The stiffer, less pliable strap material is best avoided.

Very nice pots for succulents.
I print with PLA, infill 30%, nozzle size 0.5

Printer:

Creality Ender 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Assembly:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=blm-x9pNLaM

Flight Test:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wdz6be-OQwQ

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aL6eTgz6VT0

Important Specs and info
I printed the frame out of PLA, two walls thick, with a 30% infill on my MakerGear M2. And as you can see in the video it flies very solid for using little to no hardware. Altho the spacers seem to be useless in the Quad-X frame, they play a crucial roll in the X-8 frame. Spacers on the X-8 frame should be crazy glued back to back, to help score some rigidity. Keep In mind for the X-8 you may need at least 60C discharge rate packs. To avoid cell damage and puffing. Eight motors pulling peaks of 15-18 amps at 12 volts, (3s) boils down to 1500-1700watt peaks. Amps sure do add up. Now you have a 300 size that peaks out at 1.7kw.

Motors Used: Emax 2300kv
Props: 5x6 carbon fiber
ESC: Emax 12amp
Pack: 3s 1400mah or 2200mah
Controller: CC3D, NAZE32, or APM Mini(with my personal favorite 8bit microcontroller)
Frame Weight:185 grams
X-8 Frame Weight: 270 grams
Quad-X Weight With 1400mah pack: ~1.5lbs
X-8 Weight with 2200mah pack: ~2.25lbs
Need a bag of: Hitch Pin Clips 3/16 1”

Cons (Need to be Solved)
-Mild Boom wobble
-Not made of Carbon Fiber
-A little Heavy(slowly getting stronger and lighter though)
-Currently can’t be purchased
-Requires further development
-Development account unfortunately seized by Mass.Gov

Pros
-Less then five minute frame assembly (F1 Inspired)
-Easy to repair
-No tools required for air frame assembly (AR-15 Inspired)
-Use of Hitch Pin Clips is the only hardware required for frame assembly
-Modular Design (Lego Inspired)
-Designed with Lean Manufacturing methods in mind

Hot glue works good to lock in the motor booms, and void wobble.

print_settings.Notes:: Because this is structural, I set my infill to be triangular in Simplify 3D, that way I know my structural parts are as strong as they can be. I use PETG, not PLA or ABS as PETG will outperform for this machine.

description.text:
This is for the MPCNC. I wanted a nice tall structure for my build. There is only a few ways to achieve this, and that is to brace the legs as best as you can, or go low.

I have made this to use 16mm MDF that you can get cut from your local hardware store. For me it was $1.00 per cut from a half sheet which cost me $20 all up and 30 minutes of my time. This was for me win/win since now I can get 100% square, with minimum printing and stay at a height that suited me. The top and bottom corners have been designed to pull the corners tight. The Axis ends replace the printed corners which allow the belts to be tightened in the similar fashion as the original with zip ties which work very well.

You will still need to use the original Corner Spacers as these are important to get the offset correct for the axis pipes. I have designed this for the 1 inch version as there is a bigger following of remixes etc. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1671517/

There are a few other reasons I have created the boxed version:

  1. It keeps little childrens inquisitive hands out of harm's way
  2. It keeps the dust inside the box
  3. It allows others to remix to fully enclose (which is on the "todo list")
  4. Stops it from getting the wobbles.
  5. Looks bloody cool.

Wombot Mendel

75%

Notes:

Because this is structural, I set my infill to be triangular in Simplify 3D, that way I know my structural parts are as strong as they can be. I use PETG, not PLA or ABS as PETG will outperform for this machine.

Building this

I used some tools such as a drill and cordless screwdriver. Because I have a workshop I went a little further in cabinet making and used my biscuit cutter to ensure the edges would line up. You can get away with simply drilling the ends and screwing them together. Biscuits and dowels are not required.

I cut four pieces off of the offcuts that were of equal length to support my rails in order to get the rails parallel to the base, I sat the pipes on these. I then had some tall offcuts in which I doubled up in thickness and put them in between the sides of the box and the axis rails/pipes. This gave me the required 32mm that I needed for clearance of the XY carriage.

You will now place the corner spacers in the required locations where your axis rails cross over. It is time to screw the printed ends into the side of the box. I then screw the printed top and bottom corners into place to pull the box into square and make it rigid.

Fusion 360

I took the time to measure every bit of the MPCNC end corners and location of the pipes. Thanks to the fine work of Ryan of the MPCNC this project would never have started.

author: mudcruzr

title: Audio Alert using a DFPlayer module

description.text:
Audio Alert using a DFPlayer module

https://youtu.be/I41c7qiyuZw

This Audio Alert box is placed between an audio source and an audio consumer such as an FM transmitter or amplifier. When the alert box wirelessly receives an encoded message, it breaks into the audio stream from the source and plays an mp3 sound clip. I designed the Audio Alert box for a project I recently published that detects when a wood shop dust collector is full. The original detector design would flash a warning light when the collector is full. The updated design, in addition to the flashing, now broadcasts an encoded message that is picked up by the Audio Alert box that plays an mp3 sound clip that I hear on my FM hearing protector headset. The number of messages that the Audio alert box can play/insert into the audio stream, is only limited by the number of mp3 files you can fit on a micro SD card.

I made a short video to show the Audio Alert in action. It demonstrates that it can be controlled by any device that sends a correctly encoded message. The bare PC board attached to a 9V battery is the updated dust collector full detector board.

Prints, how I printed them, you do what you think best. Both prints, 20% fill, no support.

I’ve attached a schematic and the software sources needed by Audio Alert. You’ll see that there’s an analog switch chip that is controlled by an ATtiny85 MCU. The external audio source is on by default. When a message is received the source is switched to the internal DFPlayer. The MCU tells the DFPlayer to play the mp3 file that corresponds to the message received. Once the message finishes, the source is switched back to the external source. I found that the 4066 analog switch lowered the sound level quite a bit, so the design includes a small headphone amplifier to bring the level back up.

A DFPlayer is a serially controlled mp3 player module that can be purchased for under $1.50USD if you’re willing to wait about a month for it to arrive from China. The headphone amplifier costs about the same. As noted above, the MCU is an ATtiny85, but any small MCU will work, like an Arduino Pro Mini (for under $2). I used an ATtiny85 because it’s…. tiny. The ATtiny85 maybe too challenging for some to use because it doesn’t use an external crystal. You need to tweak the internal clock to be more precise than what Amtel sets it to at the factory. I have links in the sources related to tuning the internal clock.

https://www.aliexpress.com/item/DFPlayer-Mini-MP3-Player-Module-MP3-Voice-Decode-Board-For-Arduino-Supporting-TF-Card-U-Disk/32675552627.html

https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Headphone-Amplifier-Board-Differential-Balanced-SGM-4812-HIFI-Amp-Module-150-mW/32836131575.html

VERY IMPORTANT: The DFPlayer is a 3.3 volt device. This is another reason I use the ATtiny85. The ATtiny85 runs fine a 3.3 volts. (There’s also a 3.3 volt Arduino Pro Mini).

For a voltage regulator I use a cheap DC-DC converter. I like DC-DC converters better than the LDO voltage regulators such as the AMS1117. DC-DC converters are more efficient.

https://www.aliexpress.com/item/10PCS-Mini-3A-DC-DC-Converter-Step-Down-Module-Adjustable-3V-5V-16V-Power-for-RC/32670079322.html

For the receiver I’m using an SRX882, but the more common XY-MK-5V also works well. Both work at 3.3 volts. The most important thing with these modules is the antenna. I tried a few spring antennas from various sources and one worked far and away better than the others (see link below). The difference is huge.

https://www.ebay.com/itm/10x-Helical-Spring-Screw-Antenna-315MHz-Direct-Weldment-Wholesale/262682897758

As you can see from the above link, I used 315MHz. Any frequency will work (with a properly matched antenna). For the transmitter I had a problem with the STX882. Maybe I have a few from a bad batch (I tried 2). The FS1000A worked great so long as you keep it away from the DC-DC converter.

I’m not recommending a source for the SRX882 receiver because most come bundled with the STX882 and a spring antenna . As noted this STX882 transmitter and the antenna I received with it didn’t perform very well. So look at the screenshot of the antenna in the link, and the screenshot of the hundreds of sources for receivers, and try to find one that looks like the one in the link. The thing to look for is the spacing between the coils. The bad ones are very tight, almost no space. I found this to be true for 433MHz antennas as well.

In the video you’ll see that I use a common 315MHz remote. The chip that these use to encode the message is a PT2264. It’s easy to change the code these remotes transmit by filling in and removing solder gaps that represent the bit pattern to be transmitted. I wrote a software implementation of the PT2264 chip and the corresponding PT2294 decoder chip. This is why the MCU clock needs to be somewhat precise. The Arduino Pro Mini uses an external crystal so it’s already accurate enough and therefore easier to use. Note that not all remotes use the PT2264 chip. Many look exactly like the one shown in the video. You need to look for a “fixed code” transmitter.

Other parts:
ATTINY85-20PU

  • or -
    https://www.aliexpress.com/item/WAVGAT-Atmega328-3-3V-Version-Pro-Mini-Module-8M-For-Arduino-Compatible/32827888556.html

title: Ripper's London - The Shops Part 1 - Smiths and Co

description.text:
Continuing with the Ripper's London series, these new buildings are designed as a parade of shops in Victorian London's East End. They come in five separate buildings which can be re-arranged to meet your own tastes and needs, or of course used individually (except part two which is more of an extension building above an alleyway. All those shown with signs are equipped with blank sign boards for you to choose your own retailers. Some of the buildings have archways to allow figures through to the seedy backways and alleyways of the city, where I'm sure nothing illegal ever happened (ever...)

If there are any files which seem to be missing please let me know as 5 buildings do create a fair number of files...

The Smiths and Co shop is not supposed to represent a well-known UK newsagent chain. This shop belongs to Arthur Smith and his son Reg, who are local 'financial advisors' (money lenders)
The shop on the far left on the main photo is the undertakers which appears elsewhere on Thingiverse. [https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2379905]

I originally made this and the accompanying range of 28mm buildings to accompany the "In Her Majesty's Name" set of wargaming rules by Craig Cartmell and Charles Murton, published by Osprey Wargames, and because I've been watching "Ripper Street" on that new-fangled television apparatus. I've now got carried away with my own 'Rat the Ripper' theme! The buildings should suit any variety of Victorian building usage that needs a taste of the old East End, and many of the buildings will still be alive and kicking in 'Station Roads' up and down the country and so useful for train scenery building, and various steampunk scenarios and games

Note: This series of models does not condone murder, violence or other mayhem, and sightings of the Ripper should be reported to the Metropolitan Constabulary at Great Scotland Yard preferably via telephonic device on Whitehall 1212.

description.text:
I acquired a Da Vinci 1.0a printer with repeteir 0.92 firmware. Had a 3rd party heater block that uses a removable MK8 nozzle. Printer was not set up for the extra 7mm nozzle length. Decided to move the Z axis endstop to make up for the length. Instead of adding extra wait to the moving gantry. I decided to add the spacer to the frame side of the Z axis endstop.

Feel free to adjust the Z axis scale to change the thickness of the spacer as you see fit. 7mm was just for my situation.

description.text:
This is a tool holder for the tool kit that comes with the Tevo Tornado. I always find myself looking for the stuff and now it's all sitting right next to the printer. It uses the frame to hold it up. I may do a couple of iterations of this but for now, this one works pretty well. You may have to reopen the holes if your bridging fills them in a bit. I printed it on it's side with no supports.

UPDATE I created a second version with two rails to hold the tools more upright. You can choose which one to make, they are basically the same with just the second rail added on the update.

This should work on a CR-10 as the frame is the same.

If you make one please publish a make it's what keeps me publishing to Thingiverse.

Printer:

Tevo Tornado

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 layers

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I printed in PLA using 205 C nozzle temp and 65 C bed temp for first layer then
195 C nozzle temp and 55 C bed temp for the rest of the print.

Clean up

You may need to clean out the holes depending on how good your bridging is. I printed this on its side with no supports that means the holes are bridged. The larger holes seem to do better than the smaller holes.

Quick mash up

I wanted to tidy up the tools, I was fed up with digging around in the zip lock back to find the right Allen key. I designed the legs and one hold first, I did four iterations to get it to sit right in the extruded frame. Once I was happy with that I made it big enough to put all the tools in. I measure the outside of the spanner and the Allen keys to get the hole/slot sizes.
I designed the whole thing in Fusion 360, it's a fairly simple thing so it took 2 sketches and a few extrudes.

I designed these trays to hold Warhammer Underworlds: Shadespire tokens. One tray holds objectives/shards/artifacts and dice sets, the other holds all the other tokens needed for 2 people to play and one set of dice. Feel free to tinker, remix, and print to your heart's content.

Note: I am not affiliated in any way with Games Workshop or Citadel Miniatures. I just love their games and things that are organize-y

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 / Monoprice Maker Select V2 Upgrade Part 1 - 2x30mm X-Axis / 30mm Z-Axis
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This Series will start a development of my Wanhao Duplicator i3 v2.1.

This Episode will push the X-Axis holding Frame both 30mm wider and the Bridge 30mm higher to allow further developments.

Azza´s Z-Brace will be supported.

How to:

  1. The Extensions are for the right side, print them normal oder mirrored to get 4 corners.
  2. You need longer M3 DIN912 Screws, M3 Washers, M3 Nuts.
  3. Bring the extruder to a middle position in x und y and place something under it because we touch the frame stability during the process. Turn off the printer.
  4. Remove all screws from right frame.
  5. You will need every screw 5 to 8 mm longer.
  6. Start with es bottom right corner and look at the pictures.
  7. If bottom right is installed remove the screws holding the bridge, be carful with the spin und bars and the holder of the bar.
  8. Install the top right corner as shown at the pictures.
  9. Remove the left Endstop before you remove alle screws.
  10. Continue with the top left corner.
  11. And now with the bottom left corner.
  12. You need very long screws and 4 M3 Nuts for the reinstallation of the endstop, look at the pictures.
  13. Make sure everything is at 90° and the Z-Axis left and right have the same high.
  14. Remove whatever you placed under the Printhead and try to move the Printhead from left to right. Turn on the printer if moving from left to right works.
  15. Try to move all Axis with Software like Repetier Host, if all is fine send a Home all.
  16. You can park small screws inside the unused holes for a better look. ;)

To continue: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2761839

title: Filament dispenser box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Introduction

There are many filament spool holders available, with numerous geometries and types. However, all I tried so far worked with loose spools that I had to juggle around when switching filament. I wanted a simple system which serves as filament storage and allows easy access to the filament for use.

The idea as such is not new, there are similar designs available. This solution uses regular containers available at your local hardware store and a cheap plastic pipe. Additionally some pneumatic quick connectors, Teflon tube, M4 screws and zip ties are used.

My 3D printer is placed in an Ikea box with the filament dispensers on top. A feedthrough with an additional Teflon tube brings the filament inside. So far it's been working great.

Required parts

  • Storage box (mine are approximately 370x270x270 mm)
  • Tube or similar (up to 25 mm diameter)
  • Pneumatic quick connectors + M5 nuts
  • Teflon tube
  • M4x20 screws + nuts
  • Zip ties (optional, to keep the spools in place)
